title: Deterministic computation of the characteristic polynomial in the time of matrix multiplication

sections.previous work:
Previous algorithms based on linear algebra over ùïÇùïÇ\mathbb{K} for computing the
characteristic polynomial of ùêå‚ààùïÇm√ómùêåsuperscriptùïÇùëöùëö\mathbf{{M}}\in\mathbb{K}^{m\times m} mainly fall in three
types of methods. combining the traces of the first nùëõn powers of the input matrix using
the Newton identities reveals the coefficients of the characteristic
polynomial. Known as the Faddeev-LeVerrier algorithm, it was introduced in
, refined and rediscovered in
  , and used in  to prove that
the problem is in the ùí©‚Äãùíû2ùí©superscriptùíû2\mathcal{NC}^{2} parallel complexity class. introduced in  and improved in , this
approach does not involve division, and is therefore well suited for
computing over integral domains. Later developments in this field include
[ref]1 , the latter reaching the best known cost bound of O(m2.6973log(m)c)\mathchoice{O\left(m^{2.6973}\log(m)^{c}\right)}{O(m^{2.6973}\log(m)^{c})}{O(m^{2.6973}\log(m)^{c})}{O(m^{2.6973}\log(m)^{c})}
ring operations using a deterministic algorithm, for some constant¬†c>0ùëê0c>0. based on sequences of iterates of vectors under the application of the
matrix: (ùêØ,ùêåùêØ,ùêå2‚ÄãùêØ,‚Ä¶)ùêØùêåùêØsuperscriptùêå2ùêØ‚Ä¶(\mathbf{{v}},\mathbf{{M}}\mathbf{{v}},\mathbf{{M}}^{2}\mathbf{{v}},\ldots). These methods
rely on the fact that the first linear dependency between these iterates
defines a polynomial which divides the characteristic polynomial. Some
algorithms construct the Krylov basis explicitly   , while others can be interpreted as an implicit
Krylov iteration with structured vectors [ref]12 . Methods based on traces of powers use O‚Äã(m4)ùëÇsuperscriptùëö4\mathchoice{O\left(m^{4}\right)}{O(m^{4})}{O(m^{4})}{O(m^{4})} or
O‚Äã(mœâ+1)ùëÇsuperscriptùëöùúî1\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega+1}\right)}{O(m^{\omega+1})}{O(m^{\omega+1})}{O(m^{\omega+1})} field operations, and are mostly competitive for
their parallel complexity. Methods based on determinant expansions use
O‚Äã(m4)ùëÇsuperscriptùëö4\mathchoice{O\left(m^{4}\right)}{O(m^{4})}{O(m^{4})}{O(m^{4})} or O‚Äã(mœâ+1)ùëÇsuperscriptùëöùúî1\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega+1}\right)}{O(m^{\omega+1})}{O(m^{\omega+1})}{O(m^{\omega+1})} field operations and are
relevant for division-free algorithms. Lastly, the Krylov methods run in
O‚Äã(m3)ùëÇsuperscriptùëö3\mathchoice{O\left(m^{3}\right)}{O(m^{3})}{O(m^{3})}{O(m^{3})} [ref]12  or O‚Äã(mœâ‚Äãlog‚Å°m)ùëÇsuperscriptùëöùúîùëö\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega}\log m\right)}{O(m^{\omega}\log m)}{O(m^{\omega}\log m)}{O(m^{\omega}\log m)}  field operations with deterministic algorithms, or in
O‚Äã(mœâ)ùëÇsuperscriptùëöùúî\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega}\right)}{O(m^{\omega})}{O(m^{\omega})}{O(m^{\omega})} field operations with the Las Vegas randomized
algorithm in . Note that the characteristic polynomial of ùêåùêå\mathbf{{M}} cannot be computed
faster than the determinant of ùêåùêå\mathbf{{M}}, since the latter is the constant
coefficient of the former. Furthermore, under the model of computation trees,
the determinant of m√ómùëöùëöm\times m matrices cannot be computed faster than
the product of two m√ómùëöùëöm\times m matrices
[8, Sec.‚Äâ16.4], a consequence of Baur and
Strassen‚Äôs theorem . Another type of characteristic polynomial algorithms is based on operations on

the characteristic polynomial may be obtained by calling a determinant
algorithm on the characteristic matrix x‚Äãùêàm‚àíùêåùë•subscriptùêàùëöùêåx\mathbf{{I}}_{m}-\mathbf{{M}}, which is
in ùïÇ‚Äã[x]m√ómùïÇsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùë•ùëöùëö\mathbb{K}[x]^{m\times m}. Existing algorithms, which accept any matrix in

In the last two items the cost bound is, up to logarithmic factors, the same as
the cost of multiplying matrices ùïÇ‚Äã[x]m√ómùïÇsuperscriptdelimited-[]ùë•ùëöùëö\mathbb{K}[x]^{m\times m} of degree dùëëd by

ùïÇ‚Äã[x]ùïÇdelimited-[]ùë•\mathbb{K}[x], as showed in . The last two of these cost bounds
do involve factors logarithmic in mùëöm, whereas the first two have an
exponent on mùëöm which exceeds œâùúî\omega. In summary, the fastest characteristic polynomial algorithms either are
randomized or have a cost a logarithmic factor away from the lower bound. This
paper, with Theorem¬†1.1, bridges this gap by proposing the first
deterministic algorithm with cost O‚Äã(mœâ)ùëÇsuperscriptùëöùúî\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega}\right)}{O(m^{\omega})}{O(m^{\omega})}{O(m^{\omega})}.
